This is a derivative of Johann's with the tangs removed and a portion added to screw onto a threaded top Hot End. No exta Screws!

1) Print
2) Check for fit. I rescaled this but, if it is too tight here is a good manufacturing tip. Heat the metal threaded Hot End. This one is an aluminum fitting. Heat with a small torch, soldering iron, lighter or ? Not, too hot but warm enough to soften your screw on cap. Then gently and as straight as you can begin to screw on the cap. Re-heat, adjust and screw as required untill it is seated. I had about 3 threads left at the bottom but, since this is not really high precision your parts may vary.
3) Open the bowden tube opening for a 4mm OD tube. I used a 3 or 3.5mm drill. By waiting until the fitting is screwed into place it is easy to drill out the plastic to fit a 4mm O.D. PTFE tube (bowden tube).
4)Slip an 8mm nut onto your bowden tube then push the bowden tube into your new clamp. Slide the nut down and with some force screw it onto the top clamping keeping the nut square to your Hot End.
I started with this and then saw that jamesarm97 did what I was going to do next - so you can see the other variation on ---- Thingiverse ---- Just search for it - ;-)

title: Monroe LA and LA5 series calculator digit buttons

description.text: Digit buttons for the Monroe LA and LA5 series of electromechanical calculators.

Simply use digit_button.scad in your OpenSCAD project, and call digit_button_LA(num) or digit_button_LA5(num) where num is an integer from 0 through 9.  Or use num = -1 for a blank button. The scale is 1000 units = 1 inch.
LA series buttons are slightly smaller than LA5 series buttons and have a cross-shaped bottom slot instead of a single slot. The numbers engraved on each series measure out to be the same size. 
The profile of the button is parametric, and the parameters were measured from the actual button. The parameters are shown in the file digit_button_profile.png.
The digits themselves were traced from images of the buttons. The resulting SVG files were then passed through a Python program, path.py, which converted the path to OpenSCAD polygons.
The digit_button_profile.png file, the image and SVG files, and the path.py program are included in the digit_button_src.zip file. You don't need that zip file if all you want to do is make a button.

author: robertbaruch

description.text: The original holders fit the Traxxas ball ends perfectly (thanks!), but I was too lazy to go get a piece of wood from the hardware store, then measure, cut, mark, drill, etc.  Since I already had the OpenBeam for the printer... why not just reuse it.  So I made this minor modification, reusing all the hard work for the ball-end holder shape.  Number of holders is reconfigurable.

Pretty self-explanatory: thickness should work with 8mm screws (same as for most of the Kossel frame), just slide jigs into extrusion, clip on a rod to adjust length, and tighten down.  Then do your gluing.  
I glued all rods using the same jig (one at a time)  -- but if you are too impatient for that, you could use the copy-pasted version and two (or even six?) parallel beams (untested). If you want to recompile for a different number of holders, you'll also need the STL from the source thing.

title: Raj's Minimalistic Extruder MK1 for Printrbot

description.text:
A small and quiet extruder only requiring a three parts rather than the six parts from wades extruder as well as the printrbot extruder mount system. It can also be doubled up with a mirror version for dual nozzle printing. Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4cJrrj41O5c
Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vcOqAKPWycM

I came up with this extruder inspired from the compactness of the makerbots Stepstruder. It uses pretty much the same printerbot extruder mount design, just replacing the different parts by one 2-3 plastic parts. It requires a stepstruder MK7 hobbed gear and a spring loaded bearing system of some kind. I used the Minimalistic Mk7 replacement by whosawhatsis. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718 The motor can be run cool enough to not require a fan, however a fan for the hotend may be required to stop the heat getting to the plastic. Hardware required: Nema 17 stepper
MK7 stepstruder hobbed gear
40mm fan
Bearing (623 size - 3x10x4mm)
Heavy duty spring (~30x8mm)
Hotend (16mm)
2x Linear Bearing (8mm ID, 15mmOD)
1x M3x10mm screw
6x M3x16mm screw Possible problems & tips on use:
-SPRING TENSION! (you really need a strong spring, so strong that the PLA arm hyolding the bearing flexes a little.
-STEPPER HEAT will melt the filament passing though the gear and damage the extruder where the screws tighten! (Don't run the stepper too hot, you don't need to. My printerboard has the pot set to about 25%)
-Bearing alignment, use the correct size bearing. (The design of the bearing arm by whosawhatsis has the bearing a bit off centre, either edit the file or make sure you use the right size bearing.
-Bearing binds on plastic arm (Make sure you clean up the bearing arm so nothing binds.
-Keep speed under 125mm/m or whatever your hot end allows. (You'll get slippage from the gear and the gear will get plastic all over it)
-Prevent extruder overheating due to nozzle being so close.
  • I added some foil tape behind the hot end just incase the heat affects the plastic behind it, haven't had any problems yet with up up 2 hour long prints at 215degC.
  • I didn't have the right size spring so used 5 smaller springs stacked together. An M4 screw holds them in place but doesn't tighten, allowing the top spring loaded mechanism to be released for quick filament change.
    • I have this running at 100mm/min and just printed a 2 hour print no problems, all motors cool to touch.

author: flickerfly

title: Simple Mono Fusion Button Pusher
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My second attempt at doing some 3D modeling.
I think I made it a lot better making standard peices in netfabb Studio cutting them, exporting them into Google Sketchup to hollow them out then sticking all the parts together and fixing it in netfabb Studio. Attaches over start button on Mono Fusion V2 bread plant depressing the button so you dont have to stand there with your arm in the air. The Start button when pressed forces the intermediate prover carriage to rotate without stopping. Emergency stop buttons are not affected and will still work.

Version 1.0 Tested and it didn't fit so I scraped some of the inside diameter out and cut a notch with a knife.
Then found out the cone was too low to actually press the button enough. Added a small piece of cardboard and got it working :D Version 1.2 Added notches on the sides to help with the printer not being accurate enough.
Increased the size of the central cone. Version 1.3 Scaled up 0.01 in netfabb to reduce the amount of filing on the internal diameter.
Added more notches.
Added a bit on it so I can hang it from somewhere on the machine. Version 2.0 As of yet v2.0 to be actually tested.
Removed the bit from v1.3. Was never used.
New centre prongs, supposed to be able to cut them down to fit better.
Thicker edge pieces. Previous version broke after some months. Future Thought of a better way to make it grip the button.

title: Thomas Train Double Decker Riser - TrackMaster

description.text:
My son and I spend a lot of time building TrackMaster tracks and I was disappointed that we couldn't have two tracks on top of each other. So I came up with this solution.  
In the original I put diamond cutouts in it thinking that would cut down on time and materials. I was very wrong.   
When I print two of these with the diamond pattern it takes about 9.5 hours and 92g of filament. But doing two solid risers will only take 6 hours and use 70g of filament.  
I'm leaving the old version up just in case people like the looks of it better.

author: ImmersedN3D

description.text: Here's one way to quickly detect thin defects in a spool of filament.

I have a couple bad spools of filament with both fat and thin defects. A skinny spot kills a print just like fat ones do. Fat ones can be found by drilling a hole in something and feeding the filament through, but it's not so easy and would take time to check an entire spool for thin sections with a caliper. By happy accident I found this quick and dirty method and it worked pretty well. My Afinia has a fixed bearing-to-drivegear distance and it won't feed filament thinner than 0.055 inches (1.5 mm). First set the caliper to your minimum acceptable thickness. Tighten the screw so it can't change.
Clamp the caliper horizontally to some rigid vertical surface as shown.
Thread the filament end through the wide crotch (?) of the caliper jaws.
Then run it all through from the full reel to an empty reel. If there's a thin spot (thinner than the set width of the jaws), the filament will either catch in the jaws of the caliper, or fall all the way down and out if it's really thin.
I marked bad sections with a piece of masking tape.
Raise the filament back up into the jaws or just free it from being stuck, reel in a foot or two, and continue. I used a hand cranked spool-to-spool setup and it doesn't take long to get a feel for it. Guide the filament with one hand and crank with the other.
(Hand crank files I printed a year ago are included because at least one file upload is required to publish. I do not recall any details other than they printed OK) [Edit: Slept on it and recall the cone-nut has zero clearance. Scale it up on X-Y about 2 or 3%. Took a torch to the handle end and bent it to where I wanted it. Tapped the end of the axle with a 8x1 tap to fit a short bolt, securing the handle.
Lay the "stands" flat to print. Select crank direction so the cone nut tightens rather than loosens. It needs a lock nut or something... I wouldn't design a new one like this... Buyer beware.] I ran my two troublesome spools... took about an hour.. and no longer need it, but the principle might be developed into a real project if someone cared to.

comments.text: Where do you get your filament from? I never had any problems like these.
comments.author: CFE

comments.text: I have an uncommon source. Running checks is almost mandatory. But the topic of filament tolerances is of concern to many since variations impair surface quality, layer adhesion, etc. Not everything is a printer's fault.

remixed_from.author: jfpion
remixed_from.title: y Bracket with built in tensionner

description.text:
Redesigned Y motor bracket for the Mendel Prusa 3D printer. Features top tensioner bolt to make belt tensioning easier, and it works.
Modelled in heeksCad. It is intended to work with Y-carriage I designed and which doesn't have a built-in tensioner.
The photo below with it on the end of my Mendel Prusa is to show how it fits with the rails and is not where it goes on the machine :)
Inspired by two earlier designs both of which are good ideas but needed further development - this places the adjuster on the top rail where it is easy to access and the whole thing fits better.

Just print it - I didn't need to drill out any of the holes on the one I printed.
3 perimeters, 3 layers, 0.35 nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, 25% infill at 90 degrees fill angle.
I have removed the earlier version that was a bit too tight and replaced it with Y-adj_S2d which has a corrected top rail arc.
The adjuster screw is a M4 and needs to be 40mm or more long.

comments.text: A little tip for anyone making this.. If you run into trouble with the M4 nut spinning while you try threading the M4 bolt through it, a vise is your friend.
comments.author: jkeegan

comments.text: So simple and should be able to fix my Y-axis belt tension woes.  Gonna print ASAP.  I will need to do a mirror image, however since I have my motor pointed the other way for simpler wiring sake.
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: I wish I'd thought of that - I fitted my electronics to the right hand side too :)
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Fitted the belt to this today and it seems very stable and easy to adjust. Needs a longer 4mm machine screw on mine to get the full travel - something like 40mm long would be ideal

title: NinjaFlex Guide for Printrbot V1 Extruders

description.text:
This is a tiny 'shunt' that fits into the feed cavity in my Printrbot Jr V1 extruder (which I believe is a 'Wade' type).  
They're made extra long as I'm sure there are some with variations of this type of extruder. Print and cut to desired length.  
Just slip this into the shaft below the hobbed-bolt and then feed your NinjaFlex (or filaflex, haven't tested with that). So far I've had no slop or binding with it once it was cut to the right length.  
Try it out or remix it so we can get all of our extruders to work with awesome new types of filament.

author: LootKit

description.text:
First figure created in sculptris. I'm not quite done with it, may finish up the arms and lower torso and print that as well. Guess it depends on how  much more time I want to spend on it.
Included is the source sculptris model and a pre-sliced stl for ease of use. Enjoy and show me your prints!

comments.text: Add a couple more abbs

comments.text: remarkable.

comments.text: Looking good! Thanks for introducing me to Sculptris.

comments.text: very nice!

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=16627

Using the following options: idler = 0
additional_tooth_depth = 0
retainer_ht = 2
m3_dia = 3.2
no_of_nuts = 1
idler_ht = 1.5
motor_shaft = 5.1
nut_shaft_distance = 1.2
profile = 1
m3_nut_depth = 2.7
pulley_b_dia = 20
additional_tooth_width = 0.2
teeth = 16
m3_nut_flats = 5.7
retainer = 1
pulley_b_ht = 6
m3_nut_hex = 1
pulley_t_ht = 14
nut_angle = 90

This is a derivative of Gael Langevin's original file. I have added rectangular potentiometer mounting holes to the pot mount. It seems that most of the newer HS8055bb servos are coming with the rectangular pots. These bracket have been printed and tested on my own InMoov humanoid robot.
Enjoy and I hope it saves someone some time in their own build.

I have included the step file the SolidWorks .prt file and the stl.
I printed this thing at 0.3 layer height with a 33% infill.
I was using 3mm filament @ 195 c temperature.
Enjoy and hopefully I saved you a bit of Dremel time. Tough to put a square peg in a round hole.......

comments.text:
Hi
Thanks for this. I am also looking for a replacement of TStomPotHolder for a square pot but haven't found one so far
Juerg
comments.author: juergm
